text.0:
A video that has been viewed thousands of times on Twitter claiming to show recent violence in Zanzibar following the October election is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The video is of the unrest that followed the disputed 2005 elections in Zanzibar: https://t.co/eIm8LlF6mM
text.1:
A post on Facebook promoting the use of alternative medicine as a treatment for gunshot wounds is MISLEADING.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Using coconut water in this way is not backed by science: https://t.co/z1plfN0e89
text.2:
:police_car_light: HOAX: A Facebook account using the name and image of a former commissioner of Kenya's Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) that posted a doctored photo is fake.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Dr Roselyne Akombe has distanced herself from the account: https://t.co/Yms1Y6YrhQ
text.3:
:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The healing properties of coconut water and a viral video of post-election violence are just some of the things we fact-checked this week.

:newspaper: Here are our top stories from the past seven days:
